Rats are well known for being able to chew through some very tough materials, so I thought that they could be made to become a sort of automatic miner that many people have been wanting. There would be a "carrot" and a "stick" incentive to get them to mine. The "carrot" method would be if they want something. For example, if they want food they may mine through blocks to get it. The "stick" method is when they do it to escape. If rats are cornered and you are attacking them they may mine through blocks to get away. They may also have inventories to hold the blocks they mine, although they could just drop them. If they are tamed they may bring the blocks back to you

I feel like an arthropod update is what minecraft needs, Scorpions would be a great addition as well as another favorite of mine the Lobster. Here are my ideas for the Scorpion:

2x2 is size, same an the spider

Scorpions are mostly agressive. They will stand defensively upon first seeing the player at a distance, if the player attacks the Scorpion or gets too close to it (maybe 5-7 blocks) then the scorpion will chase and attack. Scorpion attacks mainly with its pincers and has a secondary attack using its stinger which will cause the player to be briefly paralyzed.

Upon death the Scorpion drops its stinger. The stinger can be used in alchemy to craft a Potion of Paralysis and its variants.

I feel like this would bring a much needed feeling of danger inside the supposedly "hostile" biomes of the minecraft overworld.

GodRage Aonwa idea seemed pretty good too. Basing this next bit off that.
Roleplay:You're in the overworld in deep ocean and come across the water dragon. You fight, you're winning, it flees. The dragon slams downwards into the seabed, making it's own tunnel as an exit. It makes a vacuum with water flowing into a dark hole. You hesitate on the edge before proceeding forward. The screen loads and it is dark, I mean....dark.  You spawn in a completely submerged cavern of bedrock. You come to with full air supply, but you have until you drown to defeat the boss. Upon defeat, a surge of water pulls you immediately back to the overworld. You're back at the seabed with full air and with you the loot from the encounter.
Now the other dimension really isn't another 'dimension' but just a controlled realm for the 2nd combat sequence. You have ten seconds from when the dragon hits the seabed and the portal spawns to get sucked in. That leaves time for one last nibble or to think twice about following. For if you die, you lose everything on your person. If you live, the reward is up for question.

I mourn the loss of Technoblade. When watching his dad's video, it really hit home and I wept. The feels are real. Even so, stepping back and taking a bigger picture view, I will share that I do not think it would be wise or appropriate to set the precedent of Minecraft core features as a kind of memorial area. This kind of thing is appropriate for a 3rd party mod, but not a core feature. Implementing this as a feature creates an official demarcation point of value, that, as time goes on and other people from the Minecraft community pass on, will become increasingly difficult to accommodate or define. The Minecraft community is huge and has a massive number of people worthy of memorial when they pass on... it's just not a good idea to use Minecraft as a memorial, no matter how much we may care deeply about technoblade and his family.

The crocodile is a 4 block long hostile mob that will remain most of the time in the water ( usually at the bottom). When a player reaches the circle radius of the Croc, it will leap 2 blocks forward and bite the player, losing half their health if they are at the very edge of the water, and only a quarter health if they are hit at the tip. Crocodiles are very fast swimmers that can outswim you if your traveling long distances without a boat. On land, Crocs are very slow but can still bite you for a quarter of your health if you get bit. With a boat, if you swim on top of a Croc, they have the ability to knock you out of the boat and turn it into an item you must pick up.

From reddit:

ELEPHANT

Concept Art Here

Health: 60 (‚ù§Ô∏è √ó 30) | Attack Strength: Easy - 4 ‚ù§Ô∏è √ó 2), Normal - 8 (‚ù§Ô∏è √ó 4), Hard - 12 (‚ù§Ô∏è √ó 6) | Spawn: Savanna

Drops: Acacia Sapling (0‚Äì1) | Experience: 0

Basics:

  • Neutral, spawn in herds of 2-5, 5% chance to spawn as baby, not breedable
  • Passive babies, adults attack if baby is struck
  • Substantial attack reach w/ trunk
  • Immune to non-enchant Knockback
  • Slow but surprisingly quick when aggravated
  • Players can use wheat, apples, haybales to heal and get them to follow
  • Not lead-able

Key Features:

  • Can instantly destroy naturally-generated trees w/ 1x1 trunk footprint (ex. not 2x2 jungle trees); wood is dropped, leaves vanish, collects any saplings
  • Must plant a sapling w/ trunk (default acacia if none in inventory) before destroying another tree (to prevent deforestation)
  • Not tamable or rideable; babies can be befriended w/ golden apple
  • Befriended elephants give "Elephant's Strength" buff - combo of Resistance and Haste when nearby and using an axe
  • All elephants in a herd follow a leader (matriarch); leader is randomly selected within herd

Counter-points to common requests for elephants:

  • Elephants are not domesticated animals and should not "work" for the player as pets
  • Riding elephants is not ethical; elephants are sapient like dolphins
  • No ivory or leather drops - should not encourage or incentivize elephant killing in-game or IRL; best idea is to stay clear of ivory entirely

Minecraft is not just a game with the purpose to entertain people and make money. The game gave itself the responsibility to make the world a better place. Best examples of this were the implementations of dolphins, bees and pandas with whom they wanted to make the people aware of their high mortality rate.

Mojang understandably has been very hesitant with adding them because of the fact they get hunted down for their ivory, meat, skin and bones day by day. And that is something Mojang rightfully does not want to promote in the game.

But now begs the question: How to correctly add elephants to Minecraft? Let me show you my ideas, which try to emphasize the current situation as well as keep the fictional aspect of being part of a game. [1/3]

Elephant types:

  • African Elephant
    • Spawn in herds up to five (one of them is the matriarch) in the Savanna (other Savanna variations excluded), rarely with tusks
    • Bigger than the Asian equivalent
  • Asian Elephant
    • Spawn in herds up to three (one of them is the matriarch) in the Jungle Edge (other Jungle variations excluded), never with tusks
    • Smaller than the African equivalent

General behavior:

  • Passive and slow
  • Become hostile and fast after being approached too much or a cub is attacked
  • Occasionally trumpet
  • Eat leaves as well as tall grass and large fern
  • Unique animations for picking and eating their food
  • Randomly get saplings by eating, plant them by travelling around

 

Drop:

  • African elephant: Acacia or Baobab sapling
  • Asian elephant: Jungle tree sapling

Breeding:

  • Cannot be bread manually by players

[2/3]

Taming:

  • After a successful pillager raid (can be seen as poachers) in the Savanna, the matriarch of the herd can be tamed by feeding him haybales.
    • After being tamed, the rest of the herd appoints a new matriarch and moves on
  • Tamed elephants can be equipped with
    • Carpets to give them unique looks (like lamas)
    • A chest to transport items
    • Up to two saddles for two players to ride them
      • Equipment cannot be removed, carpets can be changed
    • If water nearby, tamed elephants occasionally spout water
      • If at the player friend: grants effects ‚ÄúMatriarch‚Äôs Blessing‚Äù which grants Fire Resistance for 30 seconds
      • If at hostile mobs: pushes them back and deals half a heart damage

Other:

  • In the Savanna and Jungle Edge biome, there is a chance that the Wandering Trader sits on an elephant instant of leading two lamas

In my opinion, that is the correct way to add elephants to Minecraft. Special types based on the habitat, cute behavior, no special drops and still a unique way to befriend these lovely creatures. [3/3]

I would like the way of taming foxes to be this: breed two foxes with a tame of 0 and you get a baby with a tame of 1. breed two foxes with a tame of 1 and you get a tame of two, and so on until it reaches 10. When you breed two foxes, the baby comes out with a tame that's one higher than the lowest tamed fox (if that makes sense)

T=tame amount

T0 = wild (original fox)

T1 = doesn't run away from you while walking but still does when you sprint

T2 = doesn't run away from you unless has a baby

T3 = doesn't run away from you at all

T4 = follows you

T5 = follows you and hunts like a dog (whatever you hit)

T6 = protects you from hostile mobs

T7 = Sits when you click them

T8 = prefers to sit in beds (like cats)

T9 = sleeps in your bed when you sleep

T10 = spins in circles occasionally (just to be extra adorable)

 

And each of these add up, they don't switch from one ability to another, they add another ability. example: T7 bred with T7, you now have a cat who also prefers to sit on your bed (as well as everything before that Tame level.)

The copper golem's introduction as a concept sparked an old Minecraft passion of mine. When I played Minecraft nearly 10 years ago at the time of its birth I watched the game flourish. As time went on I became obsessed with the iron giants and the many pumpkin wearing snowman that I had parade around my base. Eventually I was able to semi automate the process with redstone, pistons, and a dispenser block. Creating my own armies at my fingertips. Using snow golems and iron golems as assistants for redstone contraptions of my own. Involving pressure plates and newer blocks like trip wires or heavier pressure plates. The copper golem was introduced as the third and smallest but powerful member of a class of helpful mobs that have existed from the very beginning. With a newly introduced metal with very little uses at the moment aside from cosmetic building, lightning redirection, or a very hand spy glass, the copper golem seemed perfect to make use of all the copper in the overworld. Let's face it, you only need so many spyglasses and so many lightning rods. I'm sure that Mojang has other things planned for copper. But none will ever replace the idea of a button touching, 1x1x1 copper buddy that rusts in weather and adds to the band of mobs that have been a duo since the beginning. What I want as much as many others in this community, is to see a trio come to fruition. We want to see the copper golem enter the world and worlds we've been in, created by our own blocky hands.

Super good idea but I think it should be a way to craft a NOT super OP command block that have two uses 

  1. Create a Wither Storm
  2. Command ONE mob excluding Wither, Ender Dragon and Wither Storm.

Here is an example how to create it

Step one: Open a crafting table and create a command block core

Step two: Place the core, set one block of redstone on one side, set one block of Lapis lazuli on one side, set any type of planks on one side and one block of netherite on one side and then push them intro the core and the you have a survival command block

 

Command block core recipe:

d r e
g d i
s w f

d = block of diamond 
r = block of redstone 
e = block of emerald 
g = block of gold
d = dirt
i = block of iron
s = stone
w = water bucket

How about not

First off, a mob that slowly sucks up mobs and blocks and is basically an near-indestructible world destroyer would:

  1. Be near impossible to add, judging off of its size, its many many moving technical parts, I mean, 3 heads and a buttload of tentacles based under a huge moving body not to mention how much ai it would take to make it act realistically and grow. It would have some VERY faulty hitboxes
  2. It would be VERY laggy. The particles from the explosions paired with shadow changes from it either sucking up blocks or killing mobs in its very large range could crash games
  3. If it were to be to scale, some of it would be loaded into chunks so far from the player that they normally wouldn't even be loaded, another blow to the difficulty of the ai.
  4. The complexity of making a new enchantment, new tractor beam mechanics to force the players and blocks and mobs into it, a new crafting recipe for command blocks, and probably a new dimension (making a small pocket dimension for the inside of the wither storm would probably the EASIEST way to do it), making small sections of it detachable from endermen, etc.
  5. It would be so destructive, nobody on public servers could ever again be trusted. If anybody ever once decided they didn't like a server, they could just make a whither storm and leave. greifers would have a hayday on both creative and survival servers if this ever got added.
  6. It's all just too much trouble to add, to keep, and to monitor. I see no good reason to add it.

Whales:

Whales are passive, but be careful around them, their passive actions, (jumping, eating, barrel rolls?, singing (can cause damage that ignores armor [a blue whale's song can kill you at close range]), etc.) can deal massive damage. 

Whales have a LOT of health, and have armor points. This is due to their sheer size.

If you run into a whale in a boat, your tiny little vessel may be broken. Please remember that it is you who ran into the whale.

Whales drop a LOT of loot, (it can take up a significant portion of your inventory!) however, killing a whale can incur the wrath of the sea:

a) Whales that die out of water may explode (based on real whale corpses exploding)

b) Killing a whale may start a thunder storm (which would be especially cool if storm waves were added)

c) It may also cause Drowned (or other hostile mobs... Phantoms?) to spawn

d) may spawn a zombie whale (boss) (does the same actions as the whale, except it is trying to hurt you [so it does even more damage])

e) possible guardian spirit type thing that may spawn if you kill a whale (also boss)

Loot would include massive amounts of food & leather (possibly in the form of storage blocks/items that don't stack well), massive amounts of exp, possibly fishing loot (things the whale ate), and massive amounts of bone & bonemeal.
The Bonemeal & Exp represent ivory and whale blubber (EXP & bonemeal would probably be the closest Minecraft equivalent to oil in terms of necessity)

Breed suggestions 2/3:

Pit Bulls: Muscular dogs with high attack power and health, though lacking in speed. They indiscriminately go after any mob except for players, tamed mobs, and creepers (unless the tamed mob attacks them). Even when tamed, Pit Bulls will turn on their owners if hit one too many times. Can be found by taming a wolf with pork, around pillager outposts, or in patrols; if the leader of the latter is killed, then the Pit Bull will become friendly and can be tamed by right-clicking it with an empty hand. Found in nearly any color sans merle.

Corgis: 1-block sized dogs with decent enough attack power, though lacking in the health department. They herd livestock mobs (cows/mooshrooms, sheep, pigs, and chickens) into fenced areas; if there are no such areas nearby, then they simply round them up into a small area and keep them there. They also attack any non-player/non-tamed mobs who hurt such mobs. They can jump up to 2 and a half blocks, and can go after Phantoms. Pembroke/short-haired variants are found in plains and savanna villages, while Cardigan/long-haired ones are found in tundra and taiga villages. Both can also be obtained by feeding a wolf mutton. Pembrokes can be fawn, red, sable, and black tricolor, while Cardigans come in merle, black and white, sable, and red.

Dog breed suggestions (3/3):

St. Bernards: Gentle giants who are slow, but have above-average attack power and the second-highest health (behind wolf-dogs). They can be outfitted with chests like donkeys. Found in tundra and taiga villages, or can be tamed from wolves with beef. Comes in brown and white, red and white, or rarely off-white.

About the Boxer

A well-made Boxer in peak condition is an awesome sight. A male can stand as high as 25 inches at the shoulder; females run smaller. Their muscles ripple beneath a short, tight-fitting coat. The dark brown eyes and wrinkled forehead give the face an alert, curious look. The coat can be fawn or brindle, with white markings. Boxers move like the athletes they are named for: smooth and graceful, with a powerful forward thrust.
Boxers are upbeat and playful. Their patience and protective nature have earned them a reputation as a great dog with children. They take the jobs of watchdog and family guardian seriously and will meet threats fearlessly. Boxers do best when exposed to a lot of people and other animals in early puppyhood. Dogs are neglected in Minecraft, and I want to fix that with six new breeds: The classic Minecraft Wolf, the Labrador, the Golden retriever, the Bulldog, the Dachshund, the Husky, and the Great Dane.  The classic Wolf would function just like the Minecraft Wolves already in the game, with no special abilities.  The Labrador, found in plains, would act very loyal to its owner, and if it's owner went below 5 hp in battle, the Labrador would give its owner a little bit of regen, similar to the axolotl, but on land.  This ability would have a two minute cooldown.  The Golden Retriever, found in extreme hills, will retrieve one to four items from your drop pile for you whenever you die.  The Bulldog, most commonly found in badlands, would attack anything that comes near it except its owner, making it a good guard dog if you tie it on a lead.  The Dachshund, from savannas, would attack from four times the range of a normal dog.  The Husky, found in taigas, would be able to howl and stun enemies when it is attacked, giving them slowness and weakness for two seconds.  This ability would have a thirty-second cooldown.  And last but not least, the Great Dane, the rarest breed only from new 1.17 mountains, would give itself and its owner a new effect called Dog's Fury, which doubles the attack damage and defense.  Also, you could be able to breed two dogs, and the puppy would look like only one of its parents, but gain both's abilities, making a "superdog" with every ability possible.
